instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
Board got very small liquid damage on <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> :( an on <CHIP>U6300</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C3980</CAPACITOR>, CB701

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on F7000 got 0.14V and 0.420V in diode mode.
Big coils 0.001V in diode mode and 2 Ohm resistance to ground.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.40V

Removed F7000/1 and on pad 1 got 0.14V

Any idea where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
"L7211/21/31    4.9
L7330        28.5
L7410/20    8.7
LA640/50    1."
These are my notes, in ohm scale.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
Not short maybe.
You should compare with good board with same CPU.
i7 will give lower resistance on CPU core, as normal; no idea what CPU had the board I tested.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
Would like try to replace <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> as it is liquid damaged and got a question:
It is SIC535 and it will compatible with SIC532?

Another questions about CPU mosfets:
I see on boards SIC635, FDMF5804/08 - are they compatible or each of them are unique?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
If you find different chips in the same position on identical boards, then they are compatible; unless someone changed by error.
Sometime you can find equivalents searching on Internet; remember the case of FDMF6808 and FDMF6708/3030.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> (SIC635) just in case and the same issue but when battery is connected there is 20V and 0A from charger - is there any hope?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
Which voltages do you get on the board, w/ and w/o battery connected?
You've only mentioned <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
W/ batt got 20V and 0A from charger.
W/o batt got 5V and 0.044A from charger.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> w/o batt = 0.23V (on F7000)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> w/ batt = 10.3V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS3_G3H</SIGNAL> got 0.420V in diode mode.

All LDO's reading in diode mode are OK on all four <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.340V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages (charger only); <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.29V
VDDA = 5.05V
VDDA = 5.07V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL> - can't find that on that board, but I found <SIGNAL>EN_VR</SIGNAL> = 5.08V
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 3.40V
AMON = 0V
BOM = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
Checked that on <RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> and other side is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.34V.
<RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> got correct resistance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
Incorrect level, must be high.
One of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips pulled it down probably.
Do you get 1V1 LDO on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?

Remove USB-C connectors from shell and inspect their terminals.
You should also compare diode mode readings on J3100 and JB500 (with good board).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
All 1V1 LDOs was present.

Removed one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, checked <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> and was still stable at 0V, removed another one and then I saw pulse/spike. Putted back second chip and again was flat 0V. Replaced it with new chip and all works fine.
WOW - thank you very much for all ideas. That will help me a lot in the future. Learnt a lot from that one :)

At some post about display issue on logic board you recommend me S-EM2 EDDP & USBC Meter - do you think in that case from this post it could help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.14V and 5V 0.45A from charger.
threads.message:
On this machine, it helps to detect bad diode mode readings on J3100 and JB500.
Many of these lines are connected directly to <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
But these chips may have internal problems which don't affect the input lines.
